STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 14, 2020
Stephanie Dettloff
Child & Family Services - Northeast Michigan
1044 US-23 N
Alpena, MI 49707
RE: License #: CB040201041
Child & Family Services - Northeast Michigan
1044 US-23 N
Alpena, MI 49707
Dear Ms. Dettloff:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on February 3,
2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, Area Manager, at 616-552-3662
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 383-5531
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB040201041
Licensee Name: Child Family Services of NE Michigan
Licensee Address: 1044 US-23 N
Alpena, MI 49707
Licensee Telephone #: 989-356-4567
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Stephanie Dettloff, Designee
Name of Facility: Child & Family Services - Northeast Michigan
Facility Address: 1044 US-23 N
Alpena, MI 49707
Facility Telephone #: (989) 356-4567
Original Issuance Date: 05/01/1990
Service Types: License Foster Homes, Foster Care
Placement, Adoption evaluation and
placement. Independent Living
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection: January 6, 7, 23, and February 3, 2020

3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12209 Orientation and training.
(4) The orientation and training specified in sub-rules (1) and (2)
of this rule for each social service worker shall include all of the
following topics:
(a) Characteristics and needs of children and families served
by the agency.
(b) Requirements of applicable statutes relating to the services
the agency provides that are subject to these rules.
(c) Agency expectations for the social service worker to facilitate
and supervise the care of children and to work with families that
are served by the agency.
(d) Agency expectations for the social service worker’s role and
responsibility with foster parents and other persons who provide
care or services to children and families served by the agency.
(e) Agency expectations for developing, maintaining, and
reviewing initial and updated service plans for children and
families served by the agency.
Six personnel files were reviewed. One of 6 files reviewed did not document
orientation training for the employee.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides.
(ii) An entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state or Canadian provincial law
enforcement agency where the person usually resides.
4

Six personnel files and 1 intern file were reviewed. One of 1 intern file’s documented
that the ICHAT was completed after the interns start date. The intern started on
February 19, 2019 and the ICHAT was completed on April 8, 2019. This is a repeat
violation. The original violation was established during the renewal inspection
completed on January 15, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was received on February
19, 2019.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
Six personnel files and 1 intern file were reviewed. One of 1 intern file’s documented
that the Central Registry clearance was completed after the interns start date. The
intern started on February 19, 2019 and the clearance was completed on February
21, 2019.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
Three foster home files were reviewed. One of 3 files documented that the
application was sent to the foster parent less than 60 days before the expiration of
the license. The license was set to expire on April 16, 2019 and the application was
sent on March 7, 2019.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(2) The foster parent training plan shall provide for all of the
following:
(c) Not less than 6 hours of training annually for each
licensee after the time periods specified in subdivisions (b) of
this sub-rule.
5

Three foster home files were reviewed. One of three files documented that the foster
parent had completed first aid training only. No other training was documented.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
Three foster home files were reviewed. One of 3 files documented that the renewal
evaluation was late. The renewal was due on August 21, 2019 and was not
completed until October 17, 2019.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(2) An agency shall inform foster parents of all of the following
before they are questioned or interviewed regarding a special
evaluation:
(c) That the foster parents may involve a person of their
choice in any interviews with them involving the special
evaluation if the involvement does not impede the timely
completion of the evaluation.
Three special evaluations were reviewed. One of 3 evaluations did not document
that the foster parent was informed that he/she may involve a person of their choice
in any interviews with them involving the special evaluation if the involvement does
not impede the timely completion of the evaluation.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(a) The provision of routine medical care.
(b) The provision of emergency medical, surgical, and dental
care.
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months before
being placed in foster care or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after being placed in
foster care.
6

(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Four foster care files and 8 service plans were reviewed. One of 4 files documented
that the last physical was completed on October 17, 2017. The next physical should
have been completed within 14 months of the last physical. The file lacked the
required physical.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Four foster care files and 8 service plans were reviewed. One of 4 files documented
that the last dental exam occurred on April 3, 2018. The file lacked a current dental
exam. This is a repeat violation. The original violation was established during the
renewal inspection completed on January 15, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was
received on February 19, 2019.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
7

Four foster care files and 8 service plans were reviewed. One of 4 files contained an
USP with a due date of May 5, 2019 and it was not completed until May 10, 2019.
This is a third repeat violation. The original violation was established during the
renewal inspection completed on 11/20/17 and an acceptable CAP was received on
12/19/17. A repeat violation was established during the renewal inspection
completed on 07/26/18 and an acceptable CAP was received on 10/01/18. A second
repeat violation was established during the renewal inspection completed on
January 15, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was received on February 19, 2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and service plans
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the caseworker’s
supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age to
participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not available
or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall include an
explanation of the steps taken to involve them and shall identify
any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their participation in
services.
Four foster care files and 8 service plans were reviewed. One of 4 files did not
document the parent’s signature on the service plan dated November 30, 2019.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Reports
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
Three adoption files were reviewed. One of 3 files was missing a quarterly adoption
report. There was a gap from May 14, 2019 to November 4, 2019 when a quarterly
report was not completed.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in the
following:
8

Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to capture
family demographics, FTM logistical information, needs, strengths,
action steps, safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The DHS-
1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
Four foster care files and 8 service plans were reviewed. Two of 4 files lacked one or
more FTM’s. One file did not document that FTM’s were held for an ISP and a USP
report periods. One file did not contain the DHHS – 1105 documenting that FTM’s
were held for January 23, 2019, March 14, 2019 and October 24, 2019. This is a
second repeat violation. The original violation was established during the renewal
inspection completed on 07/26/18 and an acceptable CAP was received on
10/01/18. A repeat violation was established during the renewal inspection
completed on January 15, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was received on February
19, 2019.
FOM 722-06H Caseworker Contacts. Timely Entry of Contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
• Any face-to-face contact with children, parents, or caregivers
made by any of the following:
• Foster care caseworker/supervisor.
• CPS caseworker/supervisor.
• Adoption caseworker/supervisor.
• Permanency resource monitors.
• Education planners.
• Michigan Youth Opportunities Initiative coordinators
Four files and 8 service plans were reviewed. Three of 4 files contained social work
contacts that were entered late.
FOM 801 Medical Passports
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided to the foster care provider within two weeks of
the child's placement date. The actual date the foster care
provider receives the medical passport must be documented in
MISACWIS.
9

All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Four foster care files and 8 service plans were reviewed. Two of 4 files were lacking
documentation that medical passports were generated and provided to the caregiver
within 2 weeks of the child’s placement. One child was placed on February 28, 2019
and the first passport was completed on April 2, 2019. One file documented that the
child was placed on January 22, 2019 and there was no medical passport until July
26, 2019. This is a fourth repeat violation. The original violation was established
during the renewal inspection completed on 05/17/17 and an acceptable CAP was
received on 09/20/17. A repeat violation was established during the renewal
inspection completed on 11/20/17 and an acceptable CAP was received on
12/19/17. A second repeat violation was established during the renewal inspection
completed on 07/26/18 and an acceptable CAP was received on 10/01/18. A third
repeat violation was established during the renewal inspection completed on
January 15, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was received on February 19, 2019.
FOM 722-08C Parent Agency Treatment Plans
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
10

Four foster care files and 8 service plans were reviewed. Four of 4 files each
contained a PATP that was lacking foster parent/caregiver signatures. One file
contained a PATP dated November 11, 2019 that was not signed. One file contained
a PATP dated October 22, 2019 that was not signed. One file contained a PATP
dated February 4, 2019 that was not signed. One file contained a PATP dated
August 1, 2019 that was not signed. This is a fourth repeat violation. The original
violation was established during the renewal inspection completed on 05/17/17 and
an acceptable corrective action plan was received on 09/20/17. A repeat violation
was established during the renewal inspection 11/20/17 and an acceptable
corrective action plan was received on 12/19/17. A second repeat violation was
established during the renewal inspection completed on 07/26/18 and an acceptable
CAP was received on 10/01/18. A third repeat violation was established during the
renewal inspection completed on January 15, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was
received on February 19, 2019.
SRM 200 Fingerprints - Security Awareness Training
All personnel, contractors, vendors, and external auditors who
have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete Security
Awareness Training (SAT). Training is available on the Learning
Management System (LMS) for MDHHS personnel and contractors
with access to LMS. Non-contracted agencies will complete Finger
Print Security Awareness Training via the MDHHS public licensing
website.
SAT is required to be taken within six months of working in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all personnel with CHRI
access completes SAT timely. DCWL field consultants will monitor
completion of SAT for all CPAs as part of the annual licensing
inspection.
Three of 3 employees who have access to fingerprint/clearance information did not
have current security awareness training.
FOM 722-06H Caseworker Contacts
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact with
the child each calendar month. At least one contact each calendar
month must take place at the child’s placement location. Each con
act must include a private meeting between the child and the case-
worker; see Private Meeting in this item.
Four foster care files and 8 service plans were reviewed. Two of
4 files lacked documentation of monthly visits. One file did not
document that a visit occurred in July 2019. A second file did
11

not document that visits occurred in February and November
2019. This is a fourth repeat violation. The original violation
was established during the renewal inspection completed on
11/20/17 and an acceptable CAP was received on 12/19/17. A
repeat violation of the rule was established during the renewal
inspection completed on 07/26/18 and an acceptable CAP was
received on 10/01/18. A third repeat violation was established
during the renewal inspection completed on January 15, 2019
and an acceptable CAP was received on February 19, 2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
None required.
V. CONSULTATION
Not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency did not have any special investigations during the licensing period which
required a corrective action plan.
12

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
February 7, 2020
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 14, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
13
